skill.name: brainstorming
skill.description: You MUST use this before any creative work - creating features, building components, adding functionality, or modifying behavior. Explores user intent, requirements and design before implementation.
skill.summary: Structured brainstorming framework that transforms ideas into validated designs through collaborative dialogue, one question at a time.
skill.author: obra

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill that provides a conversational framework for brainstorming and design validation. All 14 static findings are false positives triggered by common words in documentation. No actual code execution, network calls, or dangerous operations present.

low_findings.title: Documentation False Positives
low_findings.description: Static scanner flagged common documentation terms as potential security patterns. Manual review confirms these are false positives from words like 'building', 'checking', 'commit', and 'designs' in workflow descriptions.

locations.context: Documentation contains workflow references that triggered pattern matching but pose no security risk.

evidence.context: Documentation contains workflow references that triggered pattern matching but pose no security risk.

content.value_statement: Turn rough ideas into fully formed designs through natural dialogue. This skill guides Claude Code to ask clarifying questions one at a time, explore alternatives, and present designs incrementally for validation.
actual_capabilities: Guides structured brainstorming sessions with one question at a time
Explores 2-3 alternative approaches with trade-offs before implementation
Presents designs in 200-300 word sections for incremental validation
Creates design documentation in standardized format
Integrates with git workflow for design tracking
Enforces YAGNI principles to remove unnecessary features
limitations: Does not execute code or run automated analysis
Requires active user participation to answer clarifying questions
Design quality depends on accuracy of user responses
Cannot validate technical feasibility without codebase context

use_cases.title: Product Manager: Feature Design
use_cases.description: A product manager describes a new user authentication feature. The skill asks about security requirements, user flows, and edge cases. It then presents 3 approaches (OAuth, JWT, session-based) with trade-offs, and creates a validated design document.

use_cases.title: Developer: Architecture Planning
use_cases.description: A developer wants to refactor a monolith into microservices. The skill explores service boundaries, data consistency needs, and deployment constraints. It presents the architecture incrementally, validating each component before moving forward.

use_cases.title: Team Lead: Technical Specification
use_cases.description: A team lead needs to document an API redesign. The skill asks about backwards compatibility, versioning strategy, and error handling. It produces a detailed spec covering architecture, data flow, and testing requirements.

prompt_templates.title: Simple Feature Request
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to add a logout button to my app
prompt_templates.explanation: Start with a simple feature request. The skill will ask where it should go, what should happen on click, and explore implementation options.

prompt_templates.title: Technical Component Design
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me design a caching layer for our API
prompt_templates.explanation: Describe a technical component. The skill will explore caching strategies (Redis, in-memory, CDN), invalidation patterns, and present trade-offs.

prompt_templates.title: Complex System Design
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to design a distributed job queue system that handles 10k jobs per second
prompt_templates.explanation: Complex system design. The skill will ask about failure modes, consistency requirements, monitoring needs, and present multiple architectural approaches.

prompt_templates.title: Migration Strategy
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a migration strategy to move our authentication system from sessions to JWT without downtime
prompt_templates.explanation: Migration planning with constraints. The skill will explore dual-write strategies, rollback procedures, and incremental rollout approaches with validation at each step.

output_examples.input: I want to add email notifications to my app
output_examples.output: The skill first asks: Do you want real-time notifications, batched digests, or both? After choosing real-time, it presents 3 options: webhook-based (fast, requires infrastructure), polling (simple, higher latency), or WebSocket (real-time, complex). It then shows the architecture in sections: message queue design, retry logic, and monitoring.

output_examples.input: Help me design a database schema for a blog platform
output_examples.output: Starting with questions about data relationships and query patterns, the skill explores normalization trade-offs. It presents the schema incrementally: first core tables, then relationships, then indexes. Each section asks for validation before continuing.

best_practices: Use this skill BEFORE writing code for any new feature or architectural change
Answer questions honestly about constraints and requirements - unclear answers lead to incomplete designs
Review each design section carefully before approving - it's easier to fix now than during implementation
anti_patterns: Do not skip the brainstorming phase and jump straight to coding - you will miss important requirements
Do not answer multiple-choice questions with vague responses - the skill needs clear direction
Do not approve design sections without reading them - validation prevents implementation rework

faq.question: When should I use this skill?
faq.answer: Use this before any creative work: new features, components, architectural changes, or behavior modifications. It helps avoid implementation rework by clarifying requirements upfront.

faq.question: How long does a brainstorming session take?
faq.answer: It depends on complexity. Simple features take 5-10 questions. Complex systems may need 20-30 questions. The skill asks one question at a time to avoid overwhelming you.

faq.question: Can I change my answers after the design is presented?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill validates designs incrementally. If a section does not look right, you can go back and clarify earlier answers.

faq.question: Does this skill write code?
faq.answer: No. This skill focuses on design and planning. After the design is validated, you can use other skills for implementation.

faq.question: What is YAGNI and why does this skill enforce it?
faq.answer: YAGNI means You Are Not Gonna Need It. The skill removes unnecessary features from designs to keep solutions simple and focused on actual requirements.

faq.question: Where does the design document get saved?
faq.answer: The validated design is saved to docs/plans/YYYY-MM-DD-topic-design.md and committed to git for tracking.
